text:
“When you hear
that red alert,
your heart goes from 0 to 100.”

“We have 15 seconds from the
time we hear the alarm

until we need to be inside
the bomb shelter.

But because we are the
closest to the Gaza Strip,

we don’t even have the
benefit of a full 15 seconds.”
[explosion]
“Rockets were falling.
Kids were running all over.”
“It was 11 days of battle.

11 days when my home
turned into a battlefield.”
[sirens]
[explosion]

“I think about leaving
every day —”
[explosion]

“— but I’m not
going anywhere.”
“That’s Gaza.

We’re just under two
kilometers away from it.

And if you look at a map,
we’re actually a little belly
into Gaza.

So we get rocket fire from
three possible directions.

What’s going on in Gaza
is always horrific,

but it ain’t no picnic
here either.

We have bomb shelters
here every few hundred meters
because it is ongoing,

because it could happen
at any minute.
It could happen now.

Twenty rockets or mortars
exploded in the kibbutz

during this last
round of fighting,

and 25 houses like this
were hit and damaged
to one extent or another.

So there’s a lot of
construction going around us.

Our kibbutz evacuated, but I
choose to stay here because

I think it’s important
to bear witness.
This is people who live here.

These aren’t soldiers running
around in flak jackets,
with Uzis.

These are grandmothers and
children and parents and just

normal people trying to
live out their lives.”

“I was actually in the north,
but it’s still tense.

Every alert you get on your
phone, you immediately check.

Maybe it fell or hit a house,
a kid, or somebody.
It’s really scary.”

“We had rocket attack from
Gaza for the last 20 years.

But the last month,
it was more intense.

We spent most of the time
in a bomb shelter.”

“The Iron Dome and the rocket
meet and explode in the air,

and then we have parts and
bits of Iron Dome and rocket
landing all over, around us.

A missile just landed on the
road and jumped from the road
straight into the greenhouse.

And it was just laying
there, along my peppers.”

“I saw something that I wish
I didn’t have to see.

Hamas fired a missile
at an army Jeep
just outside my house.
They killed a soldier there.

Mortars started to fall
all over the place.

And because it was
that intense,

the army brought in a tank
to protect the houses.

We did have people
in our community
that lost their life.

But if you ask me how
many people were injured —
well, everyone.
Injuries are inside.
It’s in people’s mind.”
[explosion]
“Yo!”

“If I leave my home for war,
it means I lost the war.”

“My mom, I think she’s
stronger than me.

I’m happy that there is people
like her that are ready
to live in a place like this.

They are, like, the physical
wall between Gaza and Israel
to keep us apart.

And that makes me feel safe,
and I’m happy she’s like that.

I think the first
opportunity that I have,

I will move not
as far as I can,

but somewhere that I
don’t need to be afraid.

I don’t want other kids to
have the same childhood
as I did.

We can’t get used
to it, never.”
